posts.cooked: We are using two large NEO motors on each side of our arm to lift it. We are having trouble lifting the arm and getting it to stay at a certain position. It requires a lot of force to lift when the arm is down, but even a small amount of motor power when the arm is up makes it go too far. When we apply a 0 motor power to stop the arm, it starts moving down again. Is there any way we could fix this?

posts.name: Sanjan Sen
posts.cooked: You can add a gravity torque constant based on the cosine of the angle of the arm. How heavy is the arm? You can also add a gear reduction to the motors with some max planetaries

posts.name: Spencer
posts.cooked: If possible you could add a counterweight to the arm to prevent major strain on the motors while holding. 5348 attached two trampoline springs to the chains for our arm this year and they held the arm up without any motor assistance.
How would we go about adding a constant based on the angle of the arm. How would this be calculated and would this be accurate enough to hold the arm in place without having it move?

posts.name: Sanjan Sen
posts.cooked: Yeah do you have an accurate encoder reading of your arm angle?

The two NEO motors on each side are more than powerful enough to raise the arm. The problem is that we are having difficulty stopping the arm at a certain position and figuring out what speed to move the arm based on the angle. When our arm is down, we need about 0.2-0.25 motor power to lift it up at a good speed, but when the arm is near the top (~90 degrees), anything more than 0.05 motor power makes it go too fast and hit aluminum stops we put behind the arm.
We are using a Pigeon IMU attached to the arm to read the angle. It seems to be accurate. The arm starts up inside our chassis and rotates down to about 86 degrees.

posts.name: Sanjan Sen
posts.cooked: I assume youâ€™re using PID tuning to move your arm. All you have to do is add on the cosine of your angle multiplied by some constant to your output
This sounds good, weâ€™ll try it at our meeting today. Thanks.

posts.name: Rex Hoskinson
posts.cooked: @yesiconcur 's suggestion worked for us. Thereâ€™s a lot of good dynamic feedforward example code online.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Could Be Better, Could Be Worse

posts.custom_user_title: Could Be Better, Could Be Worse

posts.name: Matt Golman
posts.cooked:
In order of priority:

Make the arm lighter. Making a large, moving part of your robot lighter is always a good idea. It will make your arm easier to move, make the robot more stable, and make the robot move faster.

Make the arm lighter. Making a large, moving part of your robot lighter is always a good idea. It will make your arm easier to move, make the robot more stable, and make the robot move faster.

Counterweight your arm with a gas shock. 3005 had a good example of this on their robot last year . This will reduce the amount of force your motors need to apply to move the arm. image 1115Ã—1623 99 KB

Counterweight your arm with a gas shock. 3005 had a good example of this on their robot last year . This will reduce the amount of force your motors need to apply to move the arm. image 1115Ã—1623 99 KB

image 1115Ã—1623 99 KB

image 1115Ã—1623 99 KB

Increase the reduction out of the motors. This will give you more force with which to move your arm.

Increase the reduction out of the motors. This will give you more force with which to move your arm.
